hints_html:
The mean of a random variable X with probability density function f(x) is given by

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{-\infty}^\infty xf(x)\,dx.\end{aligned}\]

You will need integration by parts to calculate this integral.

Choose u = x, dv = 3/10 cos(x/10) sin2(x/10). From your calculations in part (a) and (b), how can you quickly find v?

Once your integration by parts is all done you should find the integral

\[\begin{aligned} \int_0^{5\pi} \sin^3\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx\end{aligned}\]

Use the trigonometric Pythagoras to solve this integral and finish the problem.
hints_latex: You will need integration by parts to calculate this integral.

Choose \emph{u} = \emph{x}, \emph{dv} = 3/10 \emph{cos}(\emph{x}/10)
\emph{sin}\textsuperscript{2}(\emph{x}/10). From your calculations in
part (a) and (b), how can you quickly find \emph{v}?
hints_raw:
The mean of a random variable ''X'' with probability density function ''f(x)'' is given by

:<math> \int_{-\infty}^\infty xf(x)\,dx. </math>
You will need integration by parts to calculate this integral.
Choose ''u'' = ''x'', ''dv'' = 3/10 ''cos''(''x''/10) ''sin''<sup>2</sup>(''x''/10). From your calculations in part (a) and (b), how can you quickly find ''v''?
Once your integration by parts is all done you should find the integral

:<math> \int_0^{5\pi} \sin^3\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx </math>

Use the trigonometric Pythagoras to solve this integral and finish the problem.
question: 7 (c)
sols_html:
From the definition of the mean we know that we have to calculate the mean \(\mu\) by

\[\begin{aligned} \mu = \int_0^{5\pi} x\frac3{10} \cos\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\sin^2\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx.\end{aligned}\]

As suggested by the hint we choose u = x, du = dx, dv = 3/10 cos(x/10)sin2(x/10), v = ??

To find v here we use the same procedure that we already used in part (a) and part (b), i.e. the substitution y = sin(x/10) (let’s use y instead of u, since u is already in use at the integration by parts) to find

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac3{10} \cos\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\sin^2\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx &= \int 3y^2\,dy \\ &= y^3 + C \\ &= \sin^3\left(\frac{x}{10}\right) + C.\end{aligned}\]

With this intermediate result we can now go to work at calculating the mean \(\mu\):

\[\begin{aligned} \mu &= \int_0^{5\pi} \underbrace{x}_{=u} \underbrace{\frac3{10} \cos\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\sin^2\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx}_{=dv} \\ &= \left.x\sin^3\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\right|_0^{5\pi} - \int_0^{5\pi} \sin^3\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx \\ &= 5\pi - \int_0^{5\pi} \sin^3\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx\end{aligned}\]

Let’s compute the last integral separately, and only then come back to this equation. To do so, we need the trigonometric identity

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \cos^2 \theta + \sin^2 \theta = 1.\end{aligned}\]

With this we obtain

\[\begin{aligned} \int_0^{5\pi} \sin^3\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx &= \int_0^{5\pi} \sin\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\left(1-\cos^2\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\right)\,dx \\ &= \int_0^{5\pi} \sin\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx + \int_0^{5\pi} - \sin\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\cos^2\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx\end{aligned}\]

The former integral is standard, for the latter we substitute z = cos(x/10), ”dz = -1/10 sin(x/10)dx, z(0) = cos(0) = 1, z(5\(\pi\)) = cos(\(\pi\)/2) = 1. Hence

\[\begin{aligned} \int_0^{5\pi} \sin^3\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx &= \int_0^{5\pi} \sin\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx + \int_0^{5\pi} - \sin\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\cos^2\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx \\ &= \left.-10\cos\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\right|_0^{5\pi} + \int_1^0 10 z^2\,dz \\ &= 0 + 10 + \left.\frac{10}3z^3\right|_1^0 \\ &= 10 + 0 - \frac{10}{3} \\ &= \frac{20}3.\end{aligned}\]

Alright. What did we want to do with the 20/3? Right, we needed to calculate this value to find \(\mu\). Going back to the equation with \(\mu\) we can now completely the question by plugging in the result:

\[\begin{aligned} \mu &= \int_0^{5\pi} x\frac3{10} \cos\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\sin^2\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx \\ &= 5\pi - \int_0^{5\pi} \sin^3\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx \\ &= 5\pi - \frac{20}3.\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
From the definition of the mean we know that we have to calculate the
mean $\mu$ by

\begin{align*}
\mu = \int_0^{5\pi} x\frac3{10} \cos\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\sin^2\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx.
\end{align*}

As suggested by the hint we choose \emph{u} = \emph{x}, \emph{du} =
\emph{dx}, \emph{dv} = 3/10
\emph{cos}(\emph{x}/10)\emph{sin}\textsuperscript{2}(\emph{x}/10),
\emph{v} = ??

To find \emph{v} here we use the same procedure that we already used in
part (a) and part (b), i.e. the substitution \emph{y} =
\emph{sin}(\emph{x}/10) (let's use \emph{y} instead of \emph{u}, since
\emph{u} is already in use at the integration by parts) to find

\begin{align*}
\int \frac3{10} \cos\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\sin^2\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx &= \int 3y^2\,dy \\
&= y^3 + C \\
&= \sin^3\left(\frac{x}{10}\right) + C.
\end{align*}

With this intermediate result we can now go to work at calculating the
mean $\mu$:

\begin{align*}
\mu &= \int_0^{5\pi} \underbrace{x}_{=u} \underbrace{\frac3{10} \cos\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\sin^2\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx}_{=dv} \\
&= \left.x\sin^3\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\right|_0^{5\pi} - \int_0^{5\pi} \sin^3\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx \\
&= 5\pi - \int_0^{5\pi} \sin^3\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx
\end{align*}

Let's compute the last integral separately, and only then come back to
this equation. To do so, we need the trigonometric identity

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle \cos^2 \theta + \sin^2 \theta = 1.
\end{align*}

With this we obtain

\begin{align*}
\int_0^{5\pi} \sin^3\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx &= \int_0^{5\pi} \sin\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\left(1-\cos^2\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\right)\,dx \\
&= \int_0^{5\pi} \sin\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx + \int_0^{5\pi} - \sin\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\cos^2\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx
\end{align*}

The former integral is standard, for the latter we substitute \emph{z} =
\emph{cos}(\emph{x}/10), ''dz = -1/10 \emph{sin}(\emph{x}/10)\emph{dx},
\emph{z}(0) = \emph{cos}(0) = 1, \emph{z}(5$\pi$) = \emph{cos}($\pi$/2) = 1.
Hence

\begin{align*}
\int_0^{5\pi} \sin^3\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx &= \int_0^{5\pi} \sin\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx + \int_0^{5\pi} - \sin\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\cos^2\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx \\
&= \left.-10\cos\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\right|_0^{5\pi} + \int_1^0 10 z^2\,dz \\
&= 0 + 10 + \left.\frac{10}3z^3\right|_1^0 \\
&= 10 + 0 - \frac{10}{3} \\
&= \frac{20}3.
\end{align*}

Alright. What did we want to do with the 20/3? Right, we needed to
calculate this value to find $\mu$. Going back to the equation with $\mu$ we can
now completely the question by plugging in the result:

\begin{align*}
\mu &= \int_0^{5\pi} x\frac3{10} \cos\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\sin^2\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx \\
&= 5\pi - \int_0^{5\pi} \sin^3\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx \\
&= 5\pi - \frac{20}3.
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
From the definition of the mean we know that we have to calculate the mean &mu; by

:<math> \mu = \int_0^{5\pi} x\frac3{10} \cos\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\sin^2\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx. </math>

As suggested by the hint we choose ''u'' = ''x'', ''du'' = ''dx'', ''dv'' = 3/10 ''cos''(''x''/10)''sin''<sup>2</sup>(''x''/10), ''v'' = ??

To find ''v'' here we use the same procedure that we already used in part (a) and part (b), i.e. the substitution ''y'' = ''sin''(''x''/10) (let's use ''y'' instead of ''u'', since ''u'' is already in use at the integration by parts) to find

:<math> \begin{align}
\int \frac3{10} \cos\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\sin^2\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx &= \int 3y^2\,dy \\
&= y^3 + C \\
&= \sin^3\left(\frac{x}{10}\right) + C.
\end{align}
</math>

With this intermediate result we can now go to work at calculating the mean &mu;:

:<math> \begin{align}
\mu &= \int_0^{5\pi} \underbrace{x}_{=u} \underbrace{\frac3{10} \cos\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\sin^2\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx}_{=dv} \\
&= \left.x\sin^3\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\right|_0^{5\pi} - \int_0^{5\pi} \sin^3\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx \\
&= 5\pi - \int_0^{5\pi} \sin^3\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx
\end{align}
</math>

Let's compute the last integral separately, and only then come back to this equation. To do so, we need the trigonometric identity

:<math>\displaystyle \cos^2 \theta + \sin^2 \theta = 1. </math>

With this we obtain

:<math> \begin{align}
\int_0^{5\pi} \sin^3\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx &= \int_0^{5\pi} \sin\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\left(1-\cos^2\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\right)\,dx \\
&= \int_0^{5\pi} \sin\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx + \int_0^{5\pi} - \sin\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\cos^2\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx
\end{align} </math>

The former integral is standard, for the latter we substitute ''z'' = ''cos''(''x''/10), ''dz = -1/10 ''sin''(''x''/10)''dx'', ''z''(0) = ''cos''(0) = 1, ''z''(5&pi;) = ''cos''(&pi;/2) = 1. Hence

:<math> \begin{align}
\int_0^{5\pi} \sin^3\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx &= \int_0^{5\pi} \sin\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx + \int_0^{5\pi} - \sin\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\cos^2\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx \\
&= \left.-10\cos\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\right|_0^{5\pi} + \int_1^0 10 z^2\,dz \\
&= 0 + 10 + \left.\frac{10}3z^3\right|_1^0 \\
&= 10 + 0 - \frac{10}{3} \\
&= \frac{20}3.
\end{align} </math>

Alright. What did we want to do with the 20/3? Right, we needed to calculate this value to find &mu;. Going back to the equation with &mu; we can now completely the question by plugging in the result:

:<math> \begin{align}
\mu &= \int_0^{5\pi} x\frac3{10} \cos\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\sin^2\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx \\
&= 5\pi - \int_0^{5\pi} \sin^3\left(\frac{x}{10}\right)\,dx \\
&= 5\pi - \frac{20}3.
\end{align} </math>
statement_html:
The length of time in minutes it takes students to solve a certain mathematics problem (on probability) is a continuous random variable whose probability density function is

\[\begin{aligned} f(x) = \begin{cases} k\cos(x/10)\sin^2(x/10), & \text{if } 0 \leq x \leq 5\pi, \\ 0, & \text{otherwise.} \end{cases}\end{aligned}\]

(c) Compute the mean length of time required to solve the problem.
statement_raw:
The length of time in minutes it takes students to solve a certain mathematics problem (on probability) is a continuous random variable whose probability density function is

:<math> f(x) = \begin{cases} k\cos(x/10)\sin^2(x/10), & \text{if } 0 \leq x \leq 5\pi, \\
0, & \text{otherwise.} \end{cases} </math>

(c) Compute the mean length of time required to solve the problem.
